message.content:
We can write out the given information as the equations \begin{align*}
a^2+b^2+c^2&=39,\\
ab+bc+ca&=21.
\end{align*} Squaring the second equation gives $(ab)^2+2(ab)(bc)+(bc)^2+2(ab)(ca)+2(bc)(ca)+(ca)^2=21^2=441.$ This expression can be factored by grouping terms to get $(ab+bc+ca)^2+2abc(a+b+c)=441.$ Also, note that $(a^2+b^2+c^2)^2=a^4+b^4+c^4+2(a^2b^2+a^2c^2+b^2c^2).$ Expanding this equation gives $a^4+b^4+c^4+2(a^2b^2+a^2c^2+b^2c^2)=39^2=1521.$ Also, $a^4+b^4+c^4=(a^2+b^2+c^2)^2-2(a^2b^2+a^2c^2+b^2c^2)=39^2-2(21)=1365.$ Substituting this expression into the other equation gives $$1365+2(a^2b^2+a^2c^2+b^2c^2)=1521\implies 2(a^2b^2+a^2c^2+b^2c^2)=156\implies a^2b^2+a^2c^2+b^2c^2=78.$$ Subtracting twice this equation from $(ab+bc+ca)^2+2abc(a+b+c)=441$ gives \begin{align*}
441-2(ab+bc+ca)^2-4abc(a+b+c)&=441-2(21^2)-4abc(a+b+c)=\\
&=441-882-4abc (a+b+c)=\\
&=-441-4abc (a+b+c)=0,
\end{align*} so \[441=4abc(a+b+c).\] Since $a,b,$ and $c$ are nonnegative real numbers, we conclude that $abc(a+b+c)=110.$

From the equation $a^2+b^2+c^2=39=3^2+3^2+3^2$, we notice that $a,b,$ and $c$ are all less than $3$. Thus, the maximum value of $abc(a+b+c)$ occurs when $a=b=c=3$, which gives us the maximum value of \[3\cdot3\cdot3\cdot(3+3+3)=3\cdot3\cdot3\cdot9=3^3\cdot3^2=27\cdot9=243,\] which is larger than $110$. Thus, it is impossible for $abc(a+b+c)=110$, so we conclude that no solution exists with the given information.
